content.description: Stick clip preferred. Hop to the ledge and find the four-finger pockets to the left. Coast through the good holds and figure the third clip. Enjoy the last move to the anchors. Dry when raining.
content.location: Under the obvious cave to the left of a big rock on the ground that starts Talk and a Badge.

content.description: You can take the easy route and use the tree which would make it more like a 5.7. Or you can climb straight up the iron bar crimps to make a proper 5.8. Easy climbing after that.
content.location: To the left of Bam Bam on the clear face. A tree separates Bam Bam from Top Dawg.

content.description: Good holds to the crux. Pull a big move off of a two-finger pocket undercling. Powerful climbing to the anchor. Information for this entire crag was compiled by Jon Zetterberg.
content.protection: Three bolts and cold shut anchor. Bolts are not pristine
content.location: Route directly to the right of Welcome to Monterey Crag. Starts on a large rock.

content.description: Make the big move to the ledge. Traverse to the overhang and clip before you whip. A fall here swings you into a hemlock. The anchors are looking rough nowadays.
content.location: Just to the right of Suzi the Prom Queen.

content.description: Monterey Classic! Start on good holds up to the small roof crux. Find the key hold and pull the roof.
content.location: Left of Suzi Sister, in front of the Hemlock.

content.description: Great warm up. Start on good holds, long reach for the bull's horn. Take a seat to clip. Easy climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Left of Boulder problem, on the corner.

content.description: The reason for an "R" rating is due to the broken bolt on the roof. Stick clipping the bolt above the roof is possible, use caution. Good climbing to the base of the roof. Make a big move to gain the roof then easy climbing to the anchors. Top is sometimes wet.
content.location: Just right of the big cave.

content.description: The route begins with a very fun, flowy boulder problem to the first bolt. Stick clipping is not a bad idea. Continue up the 5.10+ face to the roof and get an almost no-hands rest. Pulling the roof requires some somewhat reachy moves that can be supplemented with footwork. It’s not over until you clip the chains!I would recommend back-cleaning.
content.protection: 5 bolts and anchors with rap ring lower-off.
content.location: After climbing down the wooden ladder, continue down the trail to the rock stairs. When walking down the stairs, look to your right to see the wall with an obvious roof. The route is facing the stairs and has an obvious shelf above the first bolt.

content.description: Laybacks, deadpoints, flags, a mono—what's not to love? Short but sweet. Can it pull the roof though?
content.protection: 3 bolts and anchor with rappel rings.
content.location: After climbing down the wooden ladder, continue down the trail to the rock stairs. When walking down the stairs, look to your right to see the wall with an obvious roof. This is the route in the very middle of the wall that follows some crack-like features.

content.description: Short route. Powerful first few moves. Climb the slopers and find the good side pull between bolts 2 and 3. Hit the iron bar and you're at the top.
content.location: Lone route on the bubbly face.

content.description: Great, strenuous moves along thin crack. Fitting name due to the low, tricky crux. Pass the crack, fine the rail, and you are on you way to the send. Shorter route, but fun for the grade.
content.location: Obvious crack to the right of El Toro. 5 yards left of Suzi the Prom Queen.

content.description: Slabby start on thin iron bands transition into bigger, juggy moves along arete feature. A great mixture of climbing styles! The start may get a little more difficult with time as iron bands break.
content.protection: 4 bolts and anchor with rap rings for lower off.
content.location: After climbing down the wooden ladder, turn left and walk to the first wall. This is currently the furthest route to the right if facing the wall. Look for a small arete feature.

content.description: Climb the ledges and traverse at the top to the anchors. Easy sustained 5.7.
content.location: After top dawg. On the clear face. There is a tree separating the top dawg from Bam Bam. It's to the right of the tree.

content.description: Short easy route. 2 bolts to anchors.
content.location: The first route of the Crag. Once you walk down the slab rock on the trail it is to the left.

content.description: Short, shaded crag with a variety of routes ranging from 5.6-5.12. Not crowded and has a nice, easy approach hike to the crag. Plenty of opportunity for new routes and boulder problems. Always double check bolts before climbing because some may be in need of new protection.
